text: the w50 is something that uh we realized
you know it had been 50 years since the
faculty had voted to admit women to the
2-year MBA program although there had
been women in our classrooms here um and
actually getting degrees and this really
was an opportunity for us to say okay
well what's our history been at least
around gender there's only one school
where I like the school and that was the
Harvard Business School and was based on
this book I had read and I applied to
the school with this naive notion that I
would join the faculty now there were
hardly any women in the school there
were no women on the faculty but you
know Fools Rush In Where Angels Fear To
Tread went right ahead with it
I was giving a talk at a conference and
one of the Harvard professors was in the
audience and he asked me to recruit I
told said no I actually said no two or
three times because I couldn't see
myself at Harvard Business School when I
was coming a number of people told me
this would be a disastrous place for me
to be it wasn't a place that was at all
receptive to women it wasn't a place
that was all receptive to
African-Americans that neither group had
been successful here I was very hesitant
to come here here and join the faculty
uh I must say um partly because I
thought it would be I sort of imagine
the classroom being like a big pool of
piranhas um and I thought it would be
really challenging to to teach here the
dean said you cannot teach and I said to
him this is a teaching school and he
said well we had a woman teach and it
didn't work out and Ergo women can't
teach so then I got a call from this
Dean who said they changed their minds
that they would permit me to teach and I
said okay you know it has to be that I'm
just like one of the guys the campus
physically had the feeling of being kind
of a men's
club uh a place that was built by and
for corporate Elite men I was terrified
in fact the Harvard Business School
classrooms or
amphitheaters and there's this teeny
weeny desk and I was I thought well I'll
hold on to the desk in case I feel like
fainting a funny thing happened I really
got into it I just threw myself into it
and um ended up loving it well when I
started there was it was the Brooks
Brothers era I had my ha in a very big
bun these huge glasses and I wanted to
look as old and androgynous as possible
the few of us who are there wore the
ties the little bows those Rose Bud bows
so this guy came to my class and he said
to evaluate my teaching and he said to
me you know you could look a lot better
if you change
your hair and got rid of the glasses so
that was he was evaluating me as a
female they didn't have any expectations
for women in business and so as a result
you were free to be
yourself and you could as long as you
were really doing good work and you
could you know move within the system
and and be seen you actually there was
there was no barriers I think it's very
hard when you're a young woman but life
sends you choices you make the choices
one at a time and before you know it
you'll be committed to something uh and
you will know that that's your
commitment that's your life's work the
school asks for your body and your soul
um and that's because there are so many
opportunities and they are so exciting
and it's been such a wild ride and such
an exciting rewarding ride at at the
same time it asks an enormous amount of
a of a person and I think that's the
same for women and for men I felt very
much like the trail had been blazed very
well um by many women and quite frankly
also uh a number of men who were doing
non-traditional work um similar to what
I was my research is on race and gender
relations and it was a long period of
time when that was an area that I was
advised not to do research on it wasn't
going to be rewarded it wasn't going to
be respected and um when I got here
there were plenty of people before me um
wonderful Scholars who had uh already
blazed that trail Rosabeth caner doing
really I think the best still the best
work fundamentally I you know I couldn't
I couldn't choose a better place this
community is a great research
environment it really is you will be
held to the very highest standards and
you will see the most interesting
questions I would tell Junior faculty
and especially Junior
women that HBS will stretch you and it
will broaden you in
ways that will feel very uncomfortable
sometimes if you let
it my advice is let
it because you'll be better for it
you'll grow and you'll be able to come
become more of
the great scholar and the great teacher
that that you want to be in ways that
might be somewhat surprising to
you but in ways that you'll be satisfied
with stick it out be very clear about
what you want to accomplish and ask
yourself is it worth it and if it's
worth it go ahead and do it was it
Archimedes who said Give me a lever and
if it's long enough I can move the world
I think it we have our own lever here I
mean in the sense levers each of us um
and I think HPS gives us a lever and it
gives us an opportunity to make a
difference in a way that um can really
matter
